info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued June 23 at 1:55PM MDT until June 23 at 3:45PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
info.description:
At 155 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms that produced heavy rain over the Salt Burn Scar weakening. Between 0.25 and 1.6 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts up to 0.15 of an inch are possible along the Rio Ruidoso near Glencoe. Flash flooding is ongoing with water rescues underway.
Excessive rainfall over the burn scar will impact the Rio Ruidoso to the Rio Hondo as well as Highway 70. The debris flow can consist of rock, mud, vegetation and other loose materials.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding in and around the Salt Burn Scar.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of areas in and around the Salt Burn Scar.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Ruidoso, Ruidoso Downs, Glencoe, San Patricio, Hondo, Tinnie and Hollywood.
This includes Highway 380 near Mile Marker 107.
The river level in the Rio Ruidoso at Hollywood rose by 3.5 feet in 25 minutes and the water is still rising.
info.instruction: This is a life threatening situation. Heavy rainfall caused extensive and severe flash flooding of creeks, streams and ditches in and below the Salt Burn Scar. Severe debris flows can also be anticipated across roads. Roads and driveways may be washed away in places. If you encounter flood waters, climb to safety.

parameter.value: FLASH FLOOD WARNING FOR THE SALT BURN SCAR REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 345 PM MDT THIS AFTERNOON FOR SOUTHEASTERN LINCOLN COUNTY
